title: 114_hr675
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Veterans' Compensation Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act of 2015" and includes sections on increasing rates of disability compensation and dependency and indemnity compensation. It also covers the publication of adjusted rates and the establishment of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. The "Veterans' Compensation Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act of 2015" includes provisions for extending the temporary expansion of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims, recalling retired judges, life insurance programs, voluntary contributions for survivors' annuity, judge salaries, and the selection of the chief judge. The "Veterans' Compensation Cost-of-Living Adjustment Act of 2015" includes provisions for interim payments of compensation benefits, claims processors training, notice of processing times, clarification of eligible recipients of accrued benefits, and observance of Veterans Day. Effective December 1, 2015, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs will increase dollar amounts for disability compensation and dependency and indemnity compensation. The increased amounts apply to wartime disability compensation, additional compensation for dependents, clothing allowance, and dependency and indemnity compensation to surviving spouses. The dollar amounts for disability compensation and dependency and indemnity compensation will be increased based on the percentage by which Social Security benefit amounts are increased. If the increased amount is not a whole dollar, it will be rounded down to the nearest whole dollar. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may adjust disability compensation rates for certain individuals based on Social Security benefit increases, rounding down to the nearest whole dollar amount. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will publish adjusted rates in the Federal Register, based on Social Security Act requirements. The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims will extend its temporary expansion and allow the recall of retired judges. The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims will extend its temporary expansion by allowing the recall of retired judges for a period not exceeding 90 days, based on the chief judge's certification of substantial service needs. The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims will allow the recall of retired judges for up to 90 days if there is a need for their service, based on the chief judge's certification of substantial service needs. The chief judge can terminate the recalled service if certain conditions are met. SEC. 203 amends Section 7281 of title 38, United States Code, to treat judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims as employees for life insurance purposes. The amendment applies to payments made after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 204 allows voluntary contributions to increase survivors' annuity. Section 7297 of title 38, United States Code, allows covered judges to purchase additional service credit for each year of Federal judicial service completed. Covered judges include judges in regular active service and recall-eligible retired judges. Covered judges can purchase additional service credit for Federal judicial service completed, including being permanently disabled as described in subsection (b)(4) of the code. SEC. 205 amends Section 7253(e) of title 38, United States Code, by changing "district courts" to "courts of appeals". SEC. 206 addresses the selection of the Chief Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Section 7253(d) of title 38, United States Code is amended to set age and term limits for judges of the Court. If no judge meets the requirements, the senior judge who meets the criteria will act as the chief judge. In cases where no eligible judge is available, the senior judge who meets the criteria will act as the chief judge. TITLE III--IMPROVEMENT OF CLAIMS PROCESSING

SEC. 301. INTERIM PAYMENTS OF COMPENSATION BENEFITS UNDER LAWS ADMINISTERED BY THE SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. Interim payments of compensation benefits can be made to claimants for disabilities under chapter 11 of title 38, United States Code, before the claim is fully adjudicated. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to make these interim payments based on any disability decision already made, or notify the claimant of the rating for non-compensable disabilities. Upon final adjudication, any awarded benefits will be paid to the claimant, minus the interim payments already received. Interim payments of compensation benefits can be made to claimants for disabilities under chapter 11 of title 38, United States Code, before the claim is fully adjudicated. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to make these interim payments based on any disability decision already made, or notify the claimant of the rating for non-compensable disabilities. Upon final adjudication, any awarded benefits will be paid to the claimant, minus the interim payments already received. The adjudication of a claim for disability compensation under chapter 11 requires the Secretary to make decisions on multiple disabilities, with a decision on a disability resulting in monetary benefits to the claimant. SEC. 302. CLAIMS PROCESSORS TRAINING. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a 2-year training program for newly hired claims processors without increasing processing time. Successful claims processors will assist in training. Effective 1 year after enactment.

SEC. 303. NOTICE OF AVERAGE TIMES FOR PROCESSING CLAIMS AND PERCENTAGE OF CLAIMS APPROVED. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must post information in regional offices, claims intake facilities, and on the Department's website. Applicants must receive notice of benefits and eligibility for extra benefits if they file a fully developed claim. Each person submitting a claim for benefits must acknowledge receipt of information on average processing times and the percentage of claims awarded. The information must also include the percentage of awarded benefits for different types of claims filed by veterans. Claims for benefits under the laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs can be filed by veterans who authorized a veterans service organization or another person to act on their behalf under a durable power of attorney, or by veterans who did not authorize anyone. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs accepts various types of claims for benefits, including fully developed claims in electronic or paper form, as well as claims that are not fully developed. The information regarding these claims is updated at least once each fiscal quarter. TITLE IV--OTHER MATTERS

SEC. 401. CLARIFICATION OF ELIGIBLE RECIPIENTS OF CERTAIN ACCRUED BENEFITS UPON DEATH OF BENEFICIARY. This section expands eligibility to include the estate of the veteran, effective 2 years after the enactment of this Act.

SEC. 402. OBSERVANCE OF VETERANS DAY. SEC. 402. OBSERVANCE OF VETERANS DAY. The President shall issue a proclamation for a 2-minute silence on Veterans Day to honor veterans at specific times across different time zones. "145. Veterans Day." - Passed the House of Representatives on July 28, 2015. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
